              </div></td> 
             <td>
              <div style="width:1.6em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0"> 
               <div style="height:0em;bottom:2em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #abc;padding:0;margin:0">
                &nbsp;
               </div> 
               <div style="background:#ace;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;bottom:2em;left:.2em;width:1.2em;height:0.5em;overflow:hidden">
                &nbsp;
               </div> 
               <div style="color:blue;position:absolute;bottom:.5em;left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center">
                <span style="font-size:70%">1</span>
               </div> 
               <div style="height:0em;bottom:8em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #cba;padding:0;margin:0">
                &nbsp;
               </div> 
               <div style="overflow:hidden;background:#e44;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;left:.4em;width:0.8em;bottom:7.32em;height:1.52em;">
                &nbsp;
               </div> 
               <div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:8.84em; left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center">
                <span style="font-size:80%">40</span>
               </div> 
               <div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:5.82em; left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center">
                <span style="font-size:80%">26</span>
               </div> 
              </div></td> 
            </tr> 
            <tr>
             <td colspan="12" style="padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: red">Average max. and min. temperatures in °F</td>
            </tr> 
            <tr>
             <td colspan="12" style="padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: blue">Precipitation totals in inches</td>
            </tr> 
           </tbody>
          </table> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>South Korea tends to have a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a>, and is affected by the <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_monsoon" class="mw-redirect" title="East Asian monsoon">East Asian monsoon</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">precipitation</a> heavier in summer during a short rainy season called <i><a href="/wiki/East_Asian_rainy_season" title="East Asian rainy season">jangma</a></i> (<a href="https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%EC%9E%A5%EB%A7%88" class="extiw" title="ko:장마">장마</a>), which begins end of June through the end of July. Winters can be extremely cold with the minimum temperature dropping below −20&nbsp;°C (−4&nbsp;°F) in the inland region of the country: in Seoul, the average January temperature range is −7 to 1&nbsp;°C (19 to 34&nbsp;°F), and the average August temperature range is 22 to 30&nbsp;°C (72 to 86&nbsp;°F). Winter temperatures are higher along the southern coast and considerably lower in the mountainous interior.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[147]</a></sup> Summer can be uncomfortably hot and humid, with temperatures exceeding 30&nbsp;°C (86&nbsp;°F) in most parts of the country. South Korea has four distinct seasons; spring, summer, autumn and winter. Spring usually lasts from late March to early May, summer from mid-May to early September, autumn from mid-September to early November, and winter from mid-November to mid-March. </p>
      <p>Rainfall is concentrated in the summer months of June through September. The southern coast is subject to late summer <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">typhoons</a> that bring strong winds, heavy rains and sometime floods. The average annual precipitation varies from 1,370 millimeters (54&nbsp;in) in <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a> to 1,470 millimeters (58&nbsp;in) in <a href="/wiki/Busan" title="Busan">Busan</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_South_Korea" title="Environment of South Korea">Environment of South Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pollution_in_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Pollution in South Korea">Pollution in South Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_South_Korea" title="Climate change in South Korea">Climate change in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island,_Korea.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island%2C_Korea.jpg/220px-Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island%2C_Korea.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island%2C_Korea.jpg/330px-Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island%2C_Korea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island%2C_Korea.jpg/440px-Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island%2C_Korea.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3240" data-file-height="2028"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Waterfall_on_Jeju_Island,_Korea.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Jeju_Island" title="Jeju Island">Jeju Island</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Jeju_Volcanic_Island_and_Lava_Tubes" title="Jeju Volcanic Island and Lava Tubes">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> and one of the <a href="/wiki/New7Wonders_of_Nature" title="New7Wonders of Nature">New7Wonders of Nature</a>.
        </div>

       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the first 20 years of South Korea's growth surge, little effort was made to preserve the environment.<sup id="cite_ref-google.com_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google.com-152">[148]</a></sup> Unchecked industrialization and urban development have resulted in deforestation and the ongoing destruction of wetlands such as the Songdo Tidal Flat.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[149]</a></sup> However, there have been recent efforts to balance these problems, including a government run <span class="nowrap">$84 billion</span> five-year <a href="/wiki/Green_growth" title="Green growth">green growth</a> project that aims to boost energy efficiency and green technology.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The green-based economic strategy is a comprehensive overhaul of South Korea's economy, utilizing nearly two percent of the national GDP. The greening initiative includes such efforts as a nationwide bike network, solar and wind energy, lowering oil dependent vehicles, backing daylight saving time and extensive usage of environmentally friendly technologies such as LEDs in electronics and lighting.<sup id="cite_ref-South_Korea's_green_new_deal_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-South_Korea's_green_new_deal-155">[151]</a></sup> The country – already the world's most wired – plans to build a nationwide next-generation network that will be 10 times faster than broadband facilities, in order to reduce energy usage.<sup id="cite_ref-South_Korea's_green_new_deal_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-South_Korea's_green_new_deal-155">[151]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Renewable_portfolio_standard" title="Renewable portfolio standard">renewable portfolio standard</a> program with <a href="/wiki/Renewable_Energy_Certificate_(United_States)" title="Renewable Energy Certificate (United States)">renewable energy certificates</a> runs from 2012 to 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup> Quota systems favor large, vertically integrated generators and multinational electric utilities, if only because certificates are generally denominated in units of one megawatt-hour. They are also more difficult to design and implement than a <a href="/wiki/Feed-in_tariff" title="Feed-in tariff">Feed-in tariff</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wind-works.org_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wind-works.org-157">[153]</a></sup> Around 350 residential <a href="/wiki/Micro_combined_heat_and_power" title="Micro combined heat and power">micro combined heat and power</a> units were installed in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South-Korea was in 2017 the world's 7th largest emitter of carbon emmsions And the 5th largest emitter per capita. The president <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> pledged to reduce <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gas emissions</a> which contribute to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> to zero in 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[155]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[156]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Seoul's <a href="/wiki/Tap_water" title="Tap water">tap water</a> recently became safe to drink, with city officials branding it "Arisu" in a bid to convince the public.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[157]</a></sup> Efforts have also been made with <a href="/wiki/Afforestation" title="Afforestation">afforestation</a> projects. Another multibillion-dollar project was the restoration of <a href="/wiki/Cheonggyecheon" title="Cheonggyecheon">Cheonggyecheon</a>, a stream running through downtown Seoul that had earlier been paved over by a motorway.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[158]</a></sup> One major challenge is air quality, with <a href="/wiki/Acid_rain" title="Acid rain">acid rain</a>, sulfur oxides, and annual yellow dust storms being particular problems.<sup id="cite_ref-google.com_152-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google.com-152">[148]</a></sup> It is acknowledged that many of these difficulties are a result of South Korea's proximity to China, which is a major air polluter.<sup id="cite_ref-google.com_152-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-google.com-152">[148]</a></sup> South Korea had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 6.02/10, ranking it 87th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-163">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korea is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Protocol_on_Environmental_Protection_to_the_Antarctic_Treaty" title="Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty">Antarctic-Environmental Protocol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_System" title="Antarctic Treaty System">Antarctic Treaty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Biodiversity Treaty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a> (forming the Environmental Integrity Group (EIG), regarding <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change" title="United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change">UNFCCC</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>), <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Convention_to_Combat_Desertification" title="United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification">Desertification</a>, <a href="/wiki/CITES" title="CITES">Endangered Species</a>, <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Modification_Convention" title="Environmental Modification Convention">Environmental Modification</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basel_Convention" title="Basel Convention">Hazardous Wastes</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Convention_on_the_Law_of_the_Sea" title="United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea">Law of the Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Convention_for_the_Prevention_of_Marine_Pollution_by_Dumping_from_Ships_and_Aircraft" class="mw-redirect" title="Convention for the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping from Ships and Aircraft">Marine Dumping</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_Nuclear-Test-Ban_Treaty" title="Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty">Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty</a> (not into force), <a href="/wiki/Montreal_Protocol" title="Montreal Protocol">Ozone Layer Protection</a>, <a href="/wiki/MARPOL_73/78" title="MARPOL 73/78">Ship Pollution</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Tropical_Timber_Agreement,_1983" class="mw-redirect" title="International Tropical Timber Agreement, 1983">Tropical Timber 83</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Tropical_Timber_Agreement,_1994" class="mw-redirect" title="International Tropical Timber Agreement, 1994">Tropical Timber 94</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_Convention" title="Ramsar Convention">Wetlands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/International_Convention_for_the_Regulation_of_Whaling" title="International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling">Whaling</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-165">[161]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_South_Korea" title="Government of South Korea">Government of South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_(en).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_%28en%29.svg/220px-ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_%28en%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_%28en%29.svg/330px-ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_%28en%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_%28en%29.svg/440px-ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_%28en%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="5500" data-file-height="6000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ROK_election_system_and_separation_of_powers_(en).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">Separation of powers</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_South_Korea" title="Elections in South Korea">election system</a> of South Korea
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:right; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Moon Jae-in presidential portrait.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg/120px-Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="175" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg/180px-Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg/240px-Moon_Jae-in_presidential_portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2338" data-file-height="3415"></a> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Kim Boo-kyum prime ministerial portrait.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg/120px-Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="168" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg/180px-Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg/240px-Kim_Boo-kyum_prime_ministerial_portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="591" data-file-height="827"></a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a><br><small>19th <a href="/wiki/President_of_South_Korea" title="President of South Korea">President</a></small> </td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Kim_Boo-kyum" title="Kim Boo-kyum">Kim Boo-kyum</a><br><small>47th <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_South_Korea" title="Prime Minister of South Korea">Prime Minister</a></small> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The South Korean government's structure is determined by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_South_Korea" title="Constitution of South Korea">Constitution of the Republic of Korea</a>. Like many democratic states,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup> South Korea has a government divided into three branches: <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative</a>. The executive and legislative branches operate primarily at the national level, although various ministries in the executive branch also carry out local functions. Local governments are semi-autonomous, and contain executive and <a href="/wiki/Legislative_bodies" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative bodies">legislative bodies</a> of their own. The judicial branch operates at both the national and local levels. South Korea is a constitutional democracy. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png/220px-National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png/330px-National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png/440px-National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png 2x" data-file-width="3840" data-file-height="2160"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_Building_of_the_Republic_of_Korea.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of South Korea">National Assembly of South Korea</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The constitution has been revised several times since its first promulgation in 1948 at independence. However, it has retained many broad characteristics and with the exception of the short-lived <a href="/wiki/Second_Republic_of_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Republic of South Korea">Second Republic of South Korea</a>, the country has always had a presidential system with an independent chief executive.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> Under its current constitution the state is sometimes referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Sixth_Republic_of_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Sixth Republic of South Korea">Sixth Republic of South Korea</a>. The first direct <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_South_Korea" title="Elections in South Korea">election</a> was also held in 1948. </p>
      <p>Although South Korea experienced a series of military dictatorships from the 1960s until the 1980s, it has since developed into a successful <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democracy</a>. Today, the <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> describes South Korea's democracy as a "fully functioning modern democracy".<sup id="cite_ref-ciawfb_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciawfb-168">[164]</a></sup> South Korea is ranked 45th on the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> (9th in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" title="Asia-Pacific">Asia-Pacific</a> region), with a score of 57 out of 100.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_South_Korea" title="Administrative divisions of South Korea">Administrative divisions of South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_South_Korea" title="Provinces of South Korea">Provinces of South Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Special_cities_of_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Special cities of South Korea">Special cities of South Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Korea" title="Provinces of Korea">Provinces of Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The major administrative divisions in South Korea are eight <b>provinces</b>, one <b>special self-governing province</b>, six <b>metropolitan cities</b> (self-governing cities that are not part of any province), one <b>special city</b> and one <b>special self-governing city</b>. </p> 
      <table class="wikitable"> 
       <tbody>

         <td>295,041 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="5">Province (<i>Do</i>)<sup>a</sup> </th>
        </tr>

         <td><a href="/wiki/South_Chungcheong_Province" title="South Chungcheong Province">South Chungcheong</a></td>

      <p><span style="font-size:90%;"><sup>a</sup> <a href="/wiki/Revised_Romanisation_of_Korean" class="mw-redirect" title="Revised Romanisation of Korean">Revised Romanisation</a>; <sup>b</sup> See <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Seoul" title="Names of Seoul">Names of Seoul</a>; <sup>c</sup> May As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=South_Korea&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[166]</a></sup></span> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_South_Korea" title="Demographics of South Korea">Demographics of South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Koreans" title="Koreans">Koreans</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png/220px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png/330px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png/440px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png 2x" data-file-width="610" data-file-height="425"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_S%C3%BCdkorea_2016.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population pyramid of South Korea in 2016
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <caption>
        Population<sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-171">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2019_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2019-172">[168]</a></sup> 
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th scope="col" style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th scope="col" style="background:#cfb;">Million </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>1950</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">19.2 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2000</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">47.3 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2018</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">51.2 </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>In April 2016, South Korea's population was estimated to be around 50.8 million by <a href="/wiki/National_Statistical_Office_(South_Korea)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Statistical Office (South Korea)">National Statistical Office</a>, with continuing decline of working age population and total fertility rate.<sup id="cite_ref-Kostat2016_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kostat2016-173">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KOSIS2015_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KOSIS2015-174">[170]</a></sup> The country is noted for its population density, which was an estimated 505 per square kilometer in 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-Kostat2016_173-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kostat2016-173">[169]</a></sup> more than 10 times the global average. Aside from micro-states and city-states, South Korea is the world's third most densely-populated country.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-175">[171]</a></sup> In practice the population density in much of South Korea is higher than the national one, as most of the country's land is uninhabitable due to being used for other purposes such as farming.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.com_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-175">[171]</a></sup> Most South Koreans live in urban areas, because of rapid migration from the countryside during the country's quick economic expansion in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> The capital city of <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a> is also the country's largest city and chief industrial center. According to the 2005 census, Seoul had a population of <span class="nowrap">10 million</span> inhabitants. The <a href="/wiki/Seoul_National_Capital_Area" class="mw-redirect" title="Seoul National Capital Area">Seoul National Capital Area</a> has <span class="nowrap">24.5 million</span> inhabitants (about half of South Korea's entire population) making it the world's second largest metropolitan area. Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Busan" title="Busan">Busan</a> (<span class="nowrap">3.5 million</span>), <a href="/wiki/Incheon" title="Incheon">Incheon</a> (<span class="nowrap">3.0 million</span>), <a href="/wiki/Daegu" title="Daegu">Daegu</a> (<span class="nowrap">2.5 million</span>), <a href="/wiki/Daejeon" title="Daejeon">Daejeon</a> (<span class="nowrap">1.4 million</span>), <a href="/wiki/Gwangju" title="Gwangju">Gwangju</a> (<span class="nowrap">1.4 million</span>) and <a href="/wiki/Ulsan" title="Ulsan">Ulsan</a> (<span class="nowrap">1.1 million</span>).<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Korea_Chuseok_31logo_(8046078268).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Korea_Chuseok_31logo_%288046078268%29.jpg/220px-Korea_Chuseok_31logo_%288046078268%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="242" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Korea_Chuseok_31logo_%288046078268%29.jpg/330px-Korea_Chuseok_31logo_%288046078268%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Korea_Chuseok_31logo_%288046078268%29.jpg/440px-Korea_Chuseok_31logo_%288046078268%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2303" data-file-height="2531"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Korea_Chuseok_31logo_(8046078268).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Koreans in traditional dress
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The population has also been shaped by international migration. After World War&nbsp;II and the <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Korea" title="Division of Korea">division of the Korean Peninsula</a>, about four million people from North Korea crossed the border to South Korea. This trend of net entry reversed over the next 40 years because of emigration, especially to North America through the United States and Canada. South Korea's total population in 1955 was <span class="nowrap">21.5 million</span>,<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> and has more than doubled, to 50 million, by 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-chosun1_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chosun1-179">[175]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korea is considered one of the most ethnically homogeneous societies in the world <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_South_Korea#Ethnic_groups" title="Demographics of South Korea">with ethnic Koreans representing approximately 96%</a> of total population. Precise numbers are difficult since statistics do not record ethnicity and given many <a href="/wiki/Korean_diaspora" title="Korean diaspora">immigrants are ethnically Korean</a> themselves, and some South Korean citizens are not ethnically Korean.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-180">[176]</a></sup> South Korea is nevertheless becoming a more multi-ethnic society over time <a href="/wiki/Foreigners_in_Korea" title="Foreigners in Korea">due to immigration</a>. </p>
      <p>The percentage of foreign nationals has been growing rapidly.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[177]</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=South_Korea&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, South Korea had 1,413,758 foreign residents, 2.75% of the population;<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_180-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-180">[176]</a></sup> however, many of them are ethnic Koreans with a foreign citizenship. For example, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people_in_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese people in South Korea">migrants from China (PRC)</a> make up 56.5% of foreign nationals, but approximately 70% of the Chinese citizens in Korea are <i lang="ko-Latn" title="Korean-language text"><a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_China" title="Koreans in China">Joseonjok</a></i> (<span lang="ko" title="Korean-language text">조선족</span>), PRC citizens of Korean ethnicity.<sup id="cite_ref-ChosunIlbo20090806_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChosunIlbo20090806-182">[178]</a></sup> Regardless of the ethnicity, there are 28,500 <a href="/wiki/United_States_Forces_Korea" title="United States Forces Korea">US military</a> personnel serving in South Korea, most serving a one-year unaccompanied tour (though approximately 10% serve longer tours accompanied by family), according to the Korea National Statistical Office.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup> In addition, about 43,000 English teachers from <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="English-speaking countries">English-speaking countries</a> reside temporarily in Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup> Currently, South Korea has one of the highest rates of growth of foreign born population, with about 30,000 foreign born residents obtaining South Korean citizenship every year since 2010. </p>
      <p>Large numbers of ethnic Koreans live overseas, sometimes in Korean ethnic neighbourhoods also known as <a href="/wiki/Koreatown" title="Koreatown">Koreatowns</a>. The four largest diaspora population can be found in <a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_China" title="Koreans in China">China</a> (2.3 million), the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Americans" title="Korean Americans">United States</a> (1.8 million), <a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_Japan" title="Koreans in Japan">Japan</a> (0.85 million), and <a href="/wiki/Korean_Canadians" title="Korean Canadians">Canada</a> (0.25 million). </p>
      <p>South Korea's birth rate was the world's lowest in 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[182]</a></sup> at an annual rate of approximately 9 births per 1000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[183]</a></sup> Fertility saw some modest increase afterwards,<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[184]</a></sup> but dropped to a new global low in 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[185]</a></sup> with fewer than 30,000 births per month for the first time since records began<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[186]</a></sup> and less than 1 child per woman in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[187]</a></sup> The average <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> in 2008 was 79.10 years,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup> (which was 34th in the world<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup>) but by 2015 it had increased to around 81.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[190]</a></sup> South Korea has the steepest decline in working age population of the OECD nations.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> In 2015, National Statistical Office estimated that the population of the country will have reached its peak by 2035.<sup id="cite_ref-Kostat2016_173-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kostat2016-173">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KOSIS2015_174-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KOSIS2015-174">[170]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><br> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">1</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">9,904,312</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">11</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Yongin" title="Yongin">Yongin</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Gyeonggi" class="mw-redirect" title="Gyeonggi">Gyeonggi</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">971,327 </td> 
         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg" class="image" title="Incheon"><img alt="Incheon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg/120px-Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="80" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg/180px-Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg/240px-Incheon_Grand_Bridge.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4041" data-file-height="2684"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Incheon" title="Incheon">Incheon</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg" class="image" title="Daegu"><img alt="Daegu" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg/120px-Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg/180px-Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg/240px-Daegu_from_Migliore.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Daegu" title="Daegu">Daegu</a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>

      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_South_Korea" title="Education in South Korea">Education in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:SNU_gate.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/SNU_gate.jpg/220px-SNU_gate.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/SNU_gate.jpg/330px-SNU_gate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/SNU_gate.jpg/440px-SNU_gate.jpg 2x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="438"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:SNU_gate.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Seoul_National_University" title="Seoul National University">Seoul National University</a> is considered to be the most prestigious university in South Korea.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A centralized administration in South Korea oversees the process for the education of children from kindergarten to the third and final year of high school. The school year is divided into two semesters, the first of which begins at the beginning of March and ends in mid-July, the second of which begins in late August and ends in mid-February. The schedules are not uniformly standardized and vary from school to school. Most South Korean middle schools and high schools have school uniforms, modeled on western-style uniforms. Boys' uniforms usually consist of trousers and white shirts, and girls wear skirts and white shirts (this only applies in middle schools and high schools). The country adopted a new educational program to increase the number of their foreign students through 2010. According to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education,_Science_and_Technology_(South_Korea)" title="Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (South Korea)">Ministry of Education, Science and Technology</a>, the number of scholarships for foreign students in South Korea would have (under the program) doubled by that time, and the number of foreign students would have reached 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korea is one of the top-performing <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> countries in reading literacy, mathematics and sciences with the average student scoring 519, compared with the OECD average of 492, placing it ninth in the world and has one of the world's most highly educated labor forces among OECD countries.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[195]</a></sup> The country has one of the world's highest-educated labour forces among OECD countries.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[199]</a></sup> The country is well known for its highly feverish outlook on education, where its national obsession with education has been called "education fever".<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[202]</a></sup> This obsession with education has catapulted the resource poor nation consistently atop the global education rankings where in 2014 national rankings of students' math and science scores by the Organization for Economic and Cooperation and Development (OECD), South Korea ranked second place worldwide, after Singapore.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[203]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Higher education is a serious issue in South Korea society, where it is viewed as one of the fundamental cornerstones of South Korean life. Education is regarded with a high priority for South Korean families as success in education is often a source of pride for families and within South Korean society at large, and is a necessity to improve one's socioeconomic position in South Korean society.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[204]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[205]</a></sup> South Koreans view education as the main propeller of social mobility for themselves and their family as a gateway to the South Korean middle class. Graduating from a top university is the ultimate marker of prestige, high socioeconomic status, promising marriage prospects, and a respectable career path.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup> The entrance into a top tier higher educational institution leads to a prestigious, secure and well-paid white collar job with the government, banks, or a major South Korean <a href="/wiki/Chaebol" title="Chaebol">conglomerate</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Group" title="Hyundai Group">Hyundai</a> or <a href="/wiki/LG_Electronics" title="LG Electronics">LG Electronics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pri.org_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pri.org-211">[207]</a></sup> An average South Korean child's life revolves around education as pressure to succeed academically is deeply ingrained in South Korean children from an early age. With incredible pressure on high school students to secure places at the nation's best universities, its institutional reputation and alumni networks are strong predictors of future career prospects. The top three universities in South Korea, often referred to as "SKY", are <a href="/wiki/Seoul_National_University" title="Seoul National University">Seoul National University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korea_University" title="Korea University">Korea University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yonsei_University" title="Yonsei University">Yonsei University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WeAreTeachers_Staff_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WeAreTeachers_Staff-213">[209]</a></sup> Intense competition for top grades and academic pressure to be the top student is deeply ingrained in the psyche of South Korean students at a young age.<sup id="cite_ref-WeAreTeachers_Staff_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WeAreTeachers_Staff-213">[209]</a></sup> Yet with only so many places at the nations most prestigious universities and even fewer places at top-tier companies, many young people remain disappointed and are often unwilling to lower their sights with the result of many feeling as underachievers. There is a major cultural taboo in South Korean society attached to those who have not achieved formal university education where those who do not hold university degrees face social prejudice and are often looked down by others as second-class citizens resulting in fewer opportunities for employment, improvement of one's socioeconomic position and prospects for marriage.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Na_Jeong-ju_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Na_Jeong-ju-215">[211]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KAIST_fountains_view.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/KAIST_fountains_view.jpg/220px-KAIST_fountains_view.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/KAIST_fountains_view.jpg/330px-KAIST_fountains_view.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/KAIST_fountains_view.jpg/440px-KAIST_fountains_view.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KAIST_fountains_view.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/KAIST" title="KAIST">KAIST</a> main campus in <a href="/wiki/Daejeon" title="Daejeon">Daejeon</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2015, the country spent 5.1% of its GDP on all levels of education – roughly 0.8 percentage points above the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of 4.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-216">[212]</a></sup> A strong investment in education, a militant drive for success as well as the passion for excellence has helped the resource poor country rapidly grow its economy over the past 60 years from a war torn wasteland.<sup id="cite_ref-ICEF_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ICEF-217">[213]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>International opinion regarding the South Korean education system has been divided. It has been praised for various reasons, including its comparatively high test results and its major role in ushering South Korea's <a href="/wiki/Miracle_on_the_Han_River" title="Miracle on the Han River">economic development</a> creating one of the world's most educated workforces.<sup id="cite_ref-Reeta_Chakrabarti_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reeta_Chakrabarti-218">[214]</a></sup> South Korea's highly enviable academic performance has persuaded British education ministers to actively remodel their own curriculums and exams to try to emulate Korea's militant drive and passion for excellence and high educational achievement.<sup id="cite_ref-Reeta_Chakrabarti_218-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reeta_Chakrabarti-218">[214]</a></sup> Former U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> has also praised the country's rigorous school system, where over 80 percent of South Korean high school graduates go on to university.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> The nation's high university entrance rate has created a highly skilled workforce making South Korea among the most highly educated countries in the world with one of the highest percentages of its citizens holding a tertiary education degree.<sup id="cite_ref-Korea_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korea-220">[216]</a></sup> In 2017, the country ranked fifth for the percentage of 25 to 64 year olds that have attained tertiary education with 47.7 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-Korea_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korea-220">[216]</a></sup> In addition, 69.8 percent of South Koreans aged 25–34 have completed some form of tertiary education qualification and bachelor's degrees are held by 34.2 percent of South Koreans aged 25–64, the most in the OECD.<sup id="cite_ref-auto4_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-216">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Korea_220-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korea-220">[216]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The system's rigid and hierarchical structure has been criticized for stifling creativity and innovation;<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Time_Edu_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time_Edu-222">[218]</a></sup> described as intensely and "brutally" competitive,<sup id="cite_ref-Competitive_Edu_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Competitive_Edu-223">[219]</a></sup> the system is often blamed for the high <a href="/wiki/Suicide_in_South_Korea" title="Suicide in South Korea">suicide</a> rate in the country, particularly the growing rates among those aged 10–19. Various media outlets attribute the country's high suicide rate to the nationwide anxiety around the country's college entrance exams, which determine the trajectory of students' entire lives and careers.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Suicide_Edu_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Suicide_Edu-225">[221]</a></sup> Former South Korean <i>hagwon</i> teacher Se-Woong Koo wrote that the South Korean education system amounts to <a href="/wiki/Child_abuse" title="Child abuse">child abuse</a> and that it should be "reformed and restructured without delay".<sup id="cite_ref-Se-Woong_Koo_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Se-Woong_Koo-226">[222]</a></sup> The system has also been criticized for producing an excess supply of university graduates creating an overeducated and underemployed labor force; in the first quarter of 2013 alone, nearly 3.3 million South Korean university graduates were jobless, leaving many graduates overqualified for jobs requiring less education.<sup id="cite_ref-chosun.com_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chosun.com-227">[223]</a></sup> Further criticism has been stemmed for causing labor shortages in various skilled blue collar labor and vocational occupations, where many go unfilled as the negative social stigma associated with vocational careers and not having a university degree continues to remain deep-rooted in South Korean society.<sup id="cite_ref-Na_Jeong-ju_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Na_Jeong-ju-215">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[230]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_dialects" title="Korean dialects">Korean dialects</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koreandialects.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Koreandialects.png/200px-Koreandialects.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Koreandialects.png/300px-Koreandialects.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Koreandialects.png/400px-Koreandialects.png 2x" data-file-width="422" data-file-height="441"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koreandialects.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Dialects of the Korean language
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Korean is the official language of South Korea, and is classified by most linguists as a language isolate. Korean is not related to any Chinese languages, although it incorporates a number of words that are Chinese in origin. Additionally, Korean spoken in South Korea uses a significant number of loan words from English and other European languages. Korean uses an indigenous writing system called <a href="/wiki/Hangul" title="Hangul">Hangul</a>, created in 1446 by <a href="/wiki/Sejong_the_Great" title="Sejong the Great">King Sejong</a> to provide a convenient alternative to the <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese" title="Classical Chinese">Classical Chinese</a> <a href="/wiki/Hanja" title="Hanja">Hanja</a> characters that were difficult to learn and did not fit the Korean language well. South Korea still uses some Chinese Hanja characters in limited areas, such as print media and legal documentation. </p>
      <p>The Korean language in South Korea has a <a href="/wiki/South_Korean_standard_language" title="South Korean standard language">standard dialect</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Seoul_dialect" class="mw-redirect" title="Seoul dialect">Seoul</a> (after the capital city), with an additional 4 <a href="/wiki/Korean_dialects" title="Korean dialects">Korean language dialect groups</a> in use around the country. </p>
      <p>Almost all South Korean students today learn <a href="/wiki/Education_in_South_Korea#English_education" title="Education in South Korea">English</a> throughout their education, with some optionally choosing Japanese or Mandarin as well.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_South_Korea" title="Religion in South Korea">Religion in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_South_Korea" title="Irreligion in South Korea">Irreligion in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px"> 
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black"> 
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Black"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1987.7609902728px; border-left-color:DarkOrchid"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DarkOrchid"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DarkOrchid"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 164.34184888722px; border-left-color:Yellow"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Yellow"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Yellow"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 5.0307859188983px; border-left-color:DodgerBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:37.39592057378px 92.744515333466px 0 0; border-top-color:DarkRed"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DarkRed"></div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <p>Religion in South Korea (2015 census)<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABC-CLIO_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABC-CLIO-7">[5]</a></sup> </p> 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:DarkRed; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Irreligious (56.1%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> (19.7%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Yellow; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Korean Buddhism</a> (15.5%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:DarkOrchid; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> (7.9%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Black; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Other (0.8%)
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the results of the census of 2015 more than half of the South Korean population (56.1%) declared themselves not affiliated with any <a href="/wiki/Organized_religion" title="Organized religion">religious organizations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup> In a 2012 survey, 52% declared themselves "religious", 31% said they were "not religious" and 15% identified themselves as "convinced <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[233]</a></sup> Of the people who are affiliated with a religious organization, most are <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Buddhists</a>. According to the 2015 census, 27.6% of the population were Christians (19.7% identified themselves as Protestants, 7.9% as Roman Catholics), and 15.5% were Buddhists.<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup> Other religions include <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Islam in South Korea">Islam</a> (130,000 Muslims, mostly migrant workers from Pakistan and Bangladesh but including some 35,000 Korean Muslims,<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup>) the homegrown sect of <a href="/wiki/Won_Buddhism" title="Won Buddhism">Won Buddhism</a>, and a variety of indigenous religions, including <a href="/wiki/Cheondoism" title="Cheondoism">Cheondoism</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianizing</a> religion), <a href="/wiki/Jeungsanism" title="Jeungsanism">Jeungsanism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daejongism" title="Daejongism">Daejongism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daesun_Jinrihoe" title="Daesun Jinrihoe">Daesun Jinrihoe</a> and others. <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">Freedom of religion</a> is guaranteed by the constitution, and there is no <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[235]</a></sup> Overall, between the 2005 and 2015 censuses there has been a slight decline of Christianity (down from 29% to 27.6%), a sharp decline of Buddhism (down from 22.8% to 15.5%), and a rise of the unaffiliated population (from 47.2% to 56.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Christianity is South Korea's largest organized religion, accounting for more than half of all South Korean adherents of religious organizations. There are approximately 13.5 million Christians in South Korea today; about two thirds of them belonging to Protestant churches, and the rest to the Roman Catholic Church.<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup> The number of Protestants has been stagnant throughout the 1990s and the 2000s, but increased to a peak level throughout the 2010s. Roman Catholics increased significantly between the 1980s and the 2000s, but declined throughout the 2010s.<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup> Christianity, unlike in other East Asian countries, found fertile ground in Korea in the 18th century, and by the end of the 18th century it persuaded a large part of the population as the declining monarchy supported it and opened the country to widespread proselytism as part of a project of Westernization. The weakness of Korean <a href="/wiki/Korean_shamanism" title="Korean shamanism">Sindo</a>, which, unlike Japanese <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">Shinto</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">China's religious system</a>, never developed into a national religion of high status,<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[236]</a></sup> combined with the impoverished state of <a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Korean Buddhism</a> (after 500 years of suppression at the hands of the Joseon state, by the 20th century it was virtually extinct) left a free hand to Christian churches. Christianity's similarity to native religious narratives has been studied as another factor that contributed to its success in the peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[237]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Japanese colonization</a> of the first half of the 20th century further strengthened the identification of Christianity with <a href="/wiki/Korean_nationalism" title="Korean nationalism">Korean nationalism</a>, as the Japanese coopted native Korean Sindo into the Nipponic <a href="/wiki/Shinto_in_Korea" title="Shinto in Korea">Imperial Shinto</a> that they tried to establish in the peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-242">[238]</a></sup> Widespread Christianization of the Koreans took place during State Shinto,<sup id="cite_ref-auto_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-242">[238]</a></sup> after its abolition, and then in the independent South Korea as the newly established military government supported Christianity and <a href="/wiki/Misin_tapa_undong" title="Misin tapa undong">tried to utterly oust</a> native Sindo. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_(8733836165).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_%288733836165%29.jpg/220px-KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_%288733836165%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="126" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_%288733836165%29.jpg/330px-KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_%288733836165%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_%288733836165%29.jpg/440px-KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_%288733836165%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4925" data-file-height="2829"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KOCIS_Korea_YeonDeungHoe_20130511_05_(8733836165).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Buddha%27s_Birthday" title="Buddha's Birthday">Buddha's Birthday</a> celebration in Seoul
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Among Christian denominations, <a href="/wiki/Presbyterianism_in_South_Korea" title="Presbyterianism in South Korea">Presbyterianism</a> is the largest. About nine million people belong to one of the hundred different Presbyterian churches; the biggest ones are the <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian_Church_in_Korea_(HapDong)" title="Presbyterian Church in Korea (HapDong)">HapDong Presbyterian Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian_Church_in_Korea_(TongHap)" class="mw-redirect" title="Presbyterian Church in Korea (TongHap)">TongHap Presbyterian Church</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian_Church_in_Korea_(Koshin)" class="mw-redirect" title="Presbyterian Church in Korea (Koshin)">Koshin Presbyterian Church</a>. South Korea is also the second-largest missionary-sending nation, after the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Buddhism was introduced to Korea in the 4th century.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[240]</a></sup> It became soon a dominant religion in the southeastern kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Silla" title="Silla">Silla</a>, the region that hitherto hosts the strongest concentration of Buddhists in South Korea. In the other states of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Three Kingdoms of Korea">Three Kingdoms Period</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baekje" title="Baekje">Baekje</a>, it was made the state religion respectively in 372 and 528. It remained the state religion in <a href="/wiki/Later_Silla" title="Later Silla">Later Silla</a> (<a href="/wiki/North_South_States_Period" class="mw-redirect" title="North South States Period">North South States Period</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a>. It was later suppressed throughout much of the subsequent history under the unified kingdom of Joseon (1392–1897), which officially adopted a strict <a href="/wiki/Korean_Confucianism" title="Korean Confucianism">Korean Confucianism</a>. Today, South Korea has about 7 million Buddhists,<sup id="cite_ref-2015_Census_236-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2015_Census-236">[232]</a></sup> most of them affiliated to the <a href="/wiki/Jogye_Order" title="Jogye Order">Jogye Order</a>. Most of the <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_South_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="National Treasures of South Korea">National Treasures of South Korea</a> are Buddhist artifacts. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_South_Korea" title="Health in South Korea">Health in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <p>South Korea has a <a href="/wiki/Universal_healthcare" class="mw-redirect" title="Universal healthcare">universal healthcare</a> system.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup> It has the world's second best <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Healthcare system">healthcare system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[242]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Suicide_in_South_Korea" title="Suicide in South Korea">Suicide in South Korea</a> is a serious and widespread problem and the country ranks poorly on world happiness reports for a high-income state.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[243]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Suicide_rate_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Suicide rate by country">suicide rate</a> was the highest in the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> in 2015 (24.1 deaths per 100,000 persons).<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korean hospitals have advanced medical equipment and facilities readily available, ranking 4th for <a href="/wiki/MRI" class="mw-redirect" title="MRI">MRI</a> units per capita and 6th for <a href="/wiki/CT_scanner" class="mw-redirect" title="CT scanner">CT scanners</a> per capita in the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup> It also had the OECD's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_hospital_beds" title="List of countries by hospital beds">second largest number of hospital beds per 1000 people</a> at 9.56 beds. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">Life expectancy</a> has been rising rapidly and South Korea <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">ranked 11th in the world for life expectancy</a> at 82.3 years by the <a href="/wiki/WHO" class="mw-redirect" title="WHO">WHO</a> in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[246]</a></sup> It also has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">third highest health adjusted life expectancy</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_South_Korea" title="Foreign relations of South Korea">Foreign relations of South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg/170px-Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg/255px-Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg/340px-Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2442" data-file-height="2707"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ban_Ki-Moon_Davos_2011_Cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Former <a href="/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations" title="Secretary-General of the United Nations">Secretary-General of the United Nations</a> (2007–2016), <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>South Korea maintains diplomatic relations with more than 188 countries. The country has also been a member of the United Nations since 1991, when it became a member state at the same time as North Korea. On 1 January 2007, Former South Korean Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a> served as <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Secretary-General" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Secretary-General">UN Secretary-General</a> from 2007 to 2016. It has also developed links with the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a> as both a member of <i>ASEAN Plus three,</i> a body of observers, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS). </p>
      <p>In November 2009 South Korea joined the OECD <a href="/wiki/Development_Assistance_Committee" title="Development Assistance Committee">Development Assistance Committee</a>, marking the first time a former aid recipient country joined the group as a donor member. </p>
      <p>South Korea hosted the G-20 Summit in Seoul in November 2010, a year that saw South Korea and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> conclude a <a href="/wiki/European_Union%E2%80%93South_Korea_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="European Union–South Korea Free Trade Agreement">free trade agreement</a> (FTA) to reduce trade barriers. South Korea went on to sign a <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93South_Korea_Free_Trade_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Canada–South Korea Free Trade Agreement">Free Trade Agreements with Canada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93Korea_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Australia–Korea Free Trade Agreement">Australia</a> in 2014, and another with <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_free-trade_agreements" title="New Zealand free-trade agreements">New Zealand</a> in 2015. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="North_Korea">North Korea</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="North Korea–South Korea relations">North Korea–South Korea relations</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:DMZ,_looking_at_South_(33139918525).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/DMZ%2C_looking_at_South_%2833139918525%29.jpg/220px-DMZ%2C_looking_at_South_%2833139918525%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="129" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/DMZ%2C_looking_at_South_%2833139918525%29.jpg/330px-DMZ%2C_looking_at_South_%2833139918525%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/DMZ%2C_looking_at_South_%2833139918525%29.jpg/440px-DMZ%2C_looking_at_South_%2833139918525%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4272" data-file-height="2502"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:DMZ,_looking_at_South_(33139918525).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Joint_Security_Area" title="Joint Security Area">Joint Security Area</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Both North and South Korea claim complete sovereignty over the entire peninsula and outlying islands.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup> Despite mutual animosity, reconciliation efforts have continued since the initial separation between North and South Korea. Political figures such as <a href="/wiki/Kim_Koo" class="mw-redirect" title="Kim Koo">Kim Koo</a> worked to reconcile the two governments even after the Korean War.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup> With longstanding animosity following the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> from 1950 to 1953, North Korea and South Korea signed an agreement to pursue peace.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-254">[250]</a></sup> On 4 October 2007, Roh Moo-Hyun and North Korean leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> signed an eight-point agreement on issues of permanent peace, high-level talks, economic cooperation, renewal of train services, highway and air travel, and a joint Olympic cheering squad.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_254-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-254">[250]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="665" data-file-height="521"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2018_inter-Korean_summit_01_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korean leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> and South Korean President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> shake hands inside the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Korean_Peace_House" title="Inter-Korean Peace House">Peace House</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Despite the Sunshine Policy and efforts at reconciliation, the progress was complicated by <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_missile_tests" class="mw-redirect" title="North Korean missile tests">North Korean missile tests</a> in <a href="/wiki/1993_North_Korean_missile_test" title="1993 North Korean missile test">1993</a>, <a href="/wiki/1998_North_Korean_missile_test" class="mw-redirect" title="1998 North Korean missile test">1998</a>, <a href="/wiki/2006_North_Korean_nuclear_test" title="2006 North Korean nuclear test">2006</a>, <a href="/wiki/2009_North_Korean_nuclear_test" title="2009 North Korean nuclear test">2009</a>, and 2013.
