It was not until the 1960s under the dictatorship of <a href="/wiki/Park_Chung-hee" title="Park Chung-hee">Park Chung-hee</a> where <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_South_Korea" title="Economy of South Korea">South Korea's economy</a> rapidly grew from industrialisation and the <a href="/wiki/Chaebol" title="Chaebol">Chaebol</a> corporations such as <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a> and <a href="/wiki/LG_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="LG Group">LG</a>. Ever since the industrialization of South Korea's economy, South Korea has placed its focus on technology-based corporations, which has been supported by infrastructure developments by the government. South Korean corporations <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a> and <a href="/wiki/LG" class="mw-redirect" title="LG">LG</a> were ranked first and third largest <a href="/wiki/Mobile_phone" title="Mobile phone">mobile phone</a> companies in the world in the first quarter of 2012, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[364]</a></sup> An estimated 90% of South Koreans own a mobile phone.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[365]</a></sup> Aside from placing/receiving calls and text messaging, mobile phones in the country are widely used for watching <a href="/wiki/Digital_Multimedia_Broadcasting" class="mw-redirect" title="Digital Multimedia Broadcasting">Digital Multimedia Broadcasting</a> (DMB) or viewing websites.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[366]</a></sup> Over one million DMB phones have been sold and the three major wireless communications providers <a href="/wiki/SK_Telecom" title="SK Telecom">SK Telecom</a>, <a href="/wiki/KT_(telecommunication_company)" class="mw-redirect" title="KT (telecommunication company)">KT</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LG_U%2B" class="mw-redirect" title="LG U+">LG U+</a> provide coverage in all major cities and other areas. South Korea has the fastest Internet download speeds in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[367]</a></sup> with an average download speed of 25.3 Mbit/s.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korea leads the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> in graduates in science and engineering.<sup id="cite_ref-Business_Insider_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Business_Insider-373">[369]</a></sup> From 2014 to 2019, the country ranked first among the most innovative countries in the <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Innovation_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Bloomberg Innovation Index">Bloomberg Innovation Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[371]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Bloomberg_Innovation_Index_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Bloomberg_Innovation_Index-376">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[373]</a></sup> Additionally, South Korea today is known as a Launchpad of a mature mobile market, where developers can reap benefits of a market where very few technology constraints exist. There is a growing trend of inventions of new types of media or apps, utilizing the 4G and 5G internet infrastructure in South Korea. South Korea has today the infrastructures to meet a density of population and culture that has the capability to create strong local particularity.<sup id="cite_ref-Tesla_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tesla-378">[374]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cyber_security">Cyber security</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_South_Korea" title="Internet censorship in South Korea">Internet censorship in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Following <a href="/wiki/2013_South_Korea_cyberattack" title="2013 South Korea cyberattack">cyberattacks</a> in the first half of 2013, whereby government, news-media, television station, and bank websites were compromised, the national government committed to the training of 5,000 new cybersecurity experts by 2017. The South Korean government <a href="/wiki/Bureau_121" title="Bureau 121">blamed North Korea</a> for these attacks, as well as incidents that occurred in 2009, 2011 and 2012, but Pyongyang denies the accusations.<sup id="cite_ref-Jun_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jun-379">[375]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In late September 2013, a computer-security competition jointly sponsored by the defense ministry and the National Intelligence Service was announced. The winners were announced on 29 September 2013 and shared a total prize pool of 80 million won (<a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>74,000).<sup id="cite_ref-Jun_379-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jun-379">[375]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korea's government maintains a broad-ranging approach toward the regulation of specific online content and imposes a substantial level of <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_South_Korea" title="Censorship in South Korea">censorship</a> on election-related discourse and on many websites that the government deems subversive or socially harmful.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[377]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Aerospace_engineering">Aerospace engineering</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Korea_Aerospace_Research_Institute" title="Korea Aerospace Research Institute">Korea Aerospace Research Institute</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg/170px-KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="256" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg/255px-KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg/340px-KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg 2x" data-file-width="518" data-file-height="780"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KSLV-1_Naro_Replica.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A replica of the <a href="/wiki/Naro-1" title="Naro-1">Naro-1</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>South Korea has sent up 10 satellites since 1992, all using foreign rockets and overseas launch pads, notably <a href="/wiki/Arirang-1" title="Arirang-1">Arirang-1</a> in 1999, and <a href="/wiki/Arirang-2" title="Arirang-2">Arirang-2</a> in 2006 as part of its space partnership with Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[378]</a></sup> Arirang-1 was lost in space in 2008, after nine years in service.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In April 2008, <a href="/wiki/Yi_So-yeon" title="Yi So-yeon">Yi So-yeon</a> became the first Korean to fly in space, aboard the Russian <a href="/wiki/Soyuz_TMA-12" title="Soyuz TMA-12">Soyuz TMA-12</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[381]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In June 2009, the first <a href="/wiki/Spaceport" title="Spaceport">spaceport</a> of South Korea, <a href="/wiki/Naro_Space_Center" title="Naro Space Center">Naro Space Center</a>, was completed at <a href="/wiki/Goheung" class="mw-redirect" title="Goheung">Goheung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jeollanam-do" class="mw-redirect" title="Jeollanam-do">Jeollanam-do</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> The launch of <a href="/wiki/Naro-1" title="Naro-1">Naro-1</a> in August 2009 resulted in a failure.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup> The second attempt in June 2010 was also unsuccessful.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup> However, the third launch of the Naro 1 in January 2013 was successful.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup> The government plans to develop Naro-2 by the year 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[386]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>South Korea's efforts to build an indigenous space launch vehicle have been marred due to persistent political pressure from the United States, who had for many decades hindered South Korea's indigenous rocket and missile development programs<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[387]</a></sup> in fear of their possible connection to clandestine military ballistic missile programs, which Korea many times insisted did not violate the <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> guidelines stipulated by US-Korea agreements on restriction of South Korean rocket technology research and development.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[388]</a></sup> South Korea has sought the assistance of foreign countries such as <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> through <a href="/wiki/MTCR" class="mw-redirect" title="MTCR">MTCR</a> commitments to supplement its restricted domestic rocket technology. The two failed KSLV-I <a href="/wiki/Launch_vehicle" title="Launch vehicle">launch vehicles</a> were based on the <a href="/wiki/Common_Core_Booster#Universal_Rocket_Module" title="Common Core Booster">Universal Rocket Module</a>, the first stage of the Russian <a href="/wiki/Angara_rocket" class="mw-redirect" title="Angara rocket">Angara rocket</a>, combined with a solid-fueled second stage built by South Korea. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Robotics">Robotics</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Einstein-Hubo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Einstein-Hubo.jpg/170px-Einstein-Hubo.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="267" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Einstein-Hubo.jpg/255px-Einstein-Hubo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Einstein-Hubo.jpg/340px-Einstein-Hubo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1116" data-file-height="1751"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Einstein-Hubo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Albert HUBO, developed by <a href="/wiki/KAIST" title="KAIST">KAIST</a>, can make expressive gestures with its five separate fingers.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">Robotics</a> has been included in the list of main national R&amp;D projects in Korea since 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup> In 2009, the government announced plans to build robot-themed parks in <a href="/wiki/Incheon_Free_Economic_Zone" title="Incheon Free Economic Zone">Incheon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Masan" title="Masan">Masan</a> with a mix of public and private funding.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Korea_Advanced_Institute_of_Science_and_Technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology">Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology</a> (KAIST) developed the world's second walking <a href="/wiki/Humanoid_robot" title="Humanoid robot">humanoid robot</a>, <a href="/wiki/HUBO" title="HUBO">HUBO</a>. A team in the Korea Institute of Industrial Technology developed the first Korean <a href="/wiki/Android_(robot)" title="Android (robot)">android</a>, <a href="/wiki/EveR-1" class="mw-redirect" title="EveR-1">EveR-1</a> in May 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup> EveR-1 has been succeeded by more complex models with improved movement and vision.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[392]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[393]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Plans of creating English-teaching robot assistants to compensate for the shortage of teachers were announced in February 2010, with the robots being deployed to most preschools and kindergartens by 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[394]</a></sup> Robotics are also incorporated in the entertainment sector as well; the <i>Korean Robot Game Festival</i> has been held every year since 2004 to promote science and robot technology.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[395]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biotechnology">Biotechnology</span></h3> 
      <p>Since the 1980s, the Korean government has invested in the development of a domestic <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a> industry, and the sector is projected to grow to <span class="nowrap">$6.5 billion</span> by 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup> The medical sector accounts for a large part of the production, including production of <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis_A_vaccine" title="Hepatitis A vaccine">hepatitis vaccines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antibiotic" title="Antibiotic">antibiotics</a>. </p>
      <p>Recently, research and development in <a href="/wiki/Genetics" title="Genetics">genetics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cloning" title="Cloning">cloning</a> has received increasing attention, with the first successful cloning of a dog, <a href="/wiki/Snuppy" title="Snuppy">Snuppy</a> (in 2005), and the cloning of two females of an endangered species of <a href="/wiki/Gray_wolves" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray wolves">gray wolves</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Seoul_National_University" title="Seoul National University">Seoul National University</a> in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[397]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The rapid growth of the industry has resulted in significant voids in regulation of ethics, as was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/Hwang_Woo-Suk#Controversies" class="mw-redirect" title="Hwang Woo-Suk">scientific misconduct</a> case involving <a href="/wiki/Hwang_Woo-Suk" class="mw-redirect" title="Hwang Woo-Suk">Hwang Woo-Suk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[398]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since late 2020, SK Bioscience Inc. has been producing a major proportion of the <a href="/wiki/Oxford%E2%80%93AstraZeneca_COVID-19_vaccine" title="Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine">Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine</a> for worldwide distribution through the <a href="/wiki/COVAX" title="COVAX">COVAX</a> facility under the <a href="/wiki/WHO" class="mw-redirect" title="WHO">WHO</a> hospice. A recent agreement with <a href="/wiki/Novavax" title="Novavax">Novavax</a> expands its production for a second vaccine to 40 million doses in 2022, with a $450 million investment in domestic and overseas facilities.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[399]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_South_Korea" title="Culture of South Korea">Culture of South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Korea" title="Culture of Korea">Culture of Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kayagumplayer2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Kayagumplayer2.jpg/220px-Kayagumplayer2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Kayagumplayer2.jpg/330px-Kayagumplayer2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Kayagumplayer2.jpg/440px-Kayagumplayer2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="703" data-file-height="528"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kayagumplayer2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A musician playing a <i><a href="/wiki/Gayageum" title="Gayageum">gayageum</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>South Korea shares its traditional culture with <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>, but the two Koreas have developed distinct contemporary forms of culture since the peninsula was divided in 1945. Historically, while the culture of Korea has been heavily influenced by that of neighboring China, it has nevertheless managed to develop a unique cultural identity that is distinct from its larger neighbor.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup> Its rich and vibrant culture left <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage">19 UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritages of Humanity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage#Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_by_country" title="Intangible cultural heritage">third largest in the world</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_South_Korea" title="List of World Heritage Sites in South Korea">12 World Heritage Sites</a>. The South Korean <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_and_Tourism_(South_Korea)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Culture and Tourism (South Korea)">Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism</a> actively encourages the traditional arts, as well as modern forms, through funding and education programs.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The industrialization and urbanization of South Korea have brought many changes to the way modern Koreans live. Changing economics and lifestyles have led to a concentration of population in major cities, especially the capital Seoul, with multi-generational households separating into <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_family" title="Nuclear family">nuclear family</a> living arrangements. A 2014 Euromonitor study found that South Koreans drink the most alcohol on a weekly basis compared to the rest of the world. South Koreans drink 13.7 shots of liquor per week on average and, of the 44 other countries analyzed, Russia, the Philippines, and Thailand follow.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Korean_art" title="Korean art">Korean art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg/170px-%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg/255px-%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg/340px-%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1366" data-file-height="1359"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%EC%B2%AD%ED%99%94%EB%B0%B1%EC%9E%90%EC%A7%84%EC%82%AC%EC%B1%84%EB%B3%B5%EC%88%AD%EC%95%84%EC%97%B0%EC%A0%81.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Blue and white porcelain peach-shaped water dropper from Joseon Dynasty in 18th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Korean art has been highly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhism in Korea">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_Confucianism" title="Korean Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, which can be seen in the many traditional paintings, sculptures, ceramics and the performing arts.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[403]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Korean_pottery_and_porcelain" title="Korean pottery and porcelain">Korean pottery and porcelain</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Joseon" title="Joseon">Joseon</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Joseon_white_porcelain" title="Joseon white porcelain">baekja</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Buncheong" title="Buncheong">buncheong</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Celadon" title="Celadon">celadon</a> are well known throughout the world.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[404]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Korean_tea_ceremony" title="Korean tea ceremony">Korean tea ceremony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pansori" title="Pansori">pansori</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talchum" title="Talchum">talchum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buchaechum" title="Buchaechum">buchaechum</a> are also notable Korean performing arts. </p>
      <p>Post-war modern Korean art started to flourish in the 1960s and 1970s, when South Korean artists took interest in geometrical shapes and intangible subjects. Establishing a harmony between <a href="/wiki/Man_and_nature" class="mw-redirect" title="Man and nature">man and nature</a> was also a favorite of this time. Because of social instability, social issues appeared as main subjects in the 1980s. Art was influenced by various international events and exhibits in Korea, and with it brought more diversity.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[405]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Park,_Seoul" title="Olympic Park, Seoul">Olympic Sculpture Garden</a> in 1988, the transposition of the 1993 edition of the <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Biennial" title="Whitney Biennial">Whitney Biennial</a> to Seoul,<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[406]</a></sup> the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Gwangju_Biennale" title="Gwangju Biennale">Gwangju Biennale</a><sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[407]</a></sup> and the Korean Pavilion at the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">Venice Biennale</a> in 1995<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[408]</a></sup> were notable events. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_South_Korea" title="Architecture of South Korea">Architecture of South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Korean_architecture" title="Korean architecture">Korean architecture</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sungnyemun_Gate,_front,_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Sungnyemun_Gate%2C_front%2C_2013.jpg/220px-Sungnyemun_Gate%2C_front%2C_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Sungnyemun_Gate%2C_front%2C_2013.jpg/330px-Sungnyemun_Gate%2C_front%2C_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Sungnyemun_Gate%2C_front%2C_2013.jpg/440px-Sungnyemun_Gate%2C_front%2C_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3604" data-file-height="2530"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sungnyemun_Gate,_front,_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Namdaemun" title="Namdaemun">Namdaemun</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Because of South Korea's tumultuous history, construction and destruction has been repeated endlessly, resulting in an interesting melange of architectural styles and designs.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Korean traditional architecture is characterized by its harmony with nature. Ancient architects adopted the <a href="/wiki/Bracket_(architecture)" title="Bracket (architecture)">bracket system</a> characterized by thatched roofs and heated floors called <i><a href="/wiki/Ondol" title="Ondol">ondol</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup> People of the upper classes built bigger houses with elegantly curved tiled roofs with lifting eaves. Traditional architecture can be seen in the palaces and temples, preserved old houses called <i><a href="/wiki/Hanok" title="Hanok">hanok</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[411]</a></sup> and special sites like <a href="/wiki/Hahoe_Folk_Village" title="Hahoe Folk Village">Hahoe Folk Village</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yangdong_Village_of_Gyeongju" class="mw-redirect" title="Yangdong Village of Gyeongju">Yangdong Village of Gyeongju</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_Folk_Village" title="Korean Folk Village">Korean Folk Village</a>. Traditional architecture may also be seen at the nine <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Sites">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> in South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[412]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg/220px-Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg/330px-Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg/440px-Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Daeungjeon_at_Bulguksa-Gyeongju-Korea-01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bulguksa" title="Bulguksa">Bulguksa</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Western architecture was first introduced to Korea at the end of the 19th century. Churches, offices for foreign legislation, schools and university buildings were built in new styles. With the <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">annexation of Korea by Japan in 1910</a> the colonial regime intervened in Korea's architectural heritage, and Japanese-style modern architecture was imposed. The anti-Japanese sentiment, and the Korean War, led to the destruction of most buildings constructed during that time.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Korean architecture entered a new phase of development during the post-Korean War reconstruction, incorporating modern architectural trends and styles. Stimulated by the economic growth in the 1970s and 1980s, active redevelopment saw new horizons in architectural design. In the aftermath of the 1988 Seoul Olympics, South Korea has witnessed a wide variation of styles in its architectural landscape due, in large part, to the opening up of the market to foreign architects.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup> Contemporary architectural efforts have been constantly trying to balance the traditional philosophy of "harmony with nature" and the fast-paced urbanization that the country has been going through in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[415]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Korean_cuisine" title="Korean cuisine">Korean cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg/220px-Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg/330px-Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg/440px-Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Korean.food-Bibimbap-02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bibimbap" title="Bibimbap">Bibimbap</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Korean cuisine, <i>hanguk yori</i> (한국요리; 韓國料理), or <i>hansik</i> (한식; 韓食), has evolved through centuries of social and political change. Ingredients and dishes vary by province. There are many significant regional dishes that have proliferated in different variations across the country in the present day. The <a href="/wiki/Korean_royal_court_cuisine" title="Korean royal court cuisine">Korean royal court cuisine</a> once brought all of the unique regional specialties together for the royal family. Meals consumed both by the royal family and ordinary Korean citizens have been regulated by a unique culture of etiquette. </p>
      <p>Korean cuisine is largely based on <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noodle" title="Noodle">noodles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tofu" title="Tofu">tofu</a>, vegetables, fish and meats. Traditional Korean meals are noted for the number of side dishes, <i><a href="/wiki/Banchan" title="Banchan">banchan</a></i> (반찬), which accompany steam-cooked short-grain rice. Every meal is accompanied by numerous banchan. <a href="/wiki/Kimchi" title="Kimchi">Kimchi</a> (김치), a fermented, usually spicy vegetable dish is commonly served at every meal and is one of the best known Korean dishes. Korean cuisine usually involves heavy seasoning with <a href="/wiki/Sesame_oil" title="Sesame oil">sesame oil</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Doenjang" title="Doenjang">doenjang</a></i> (된장), a type of <a href="/wiki/Fermented_bean_paste" title="Fermented bean paste">fermented soybean paste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_soy_sauce" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean soy sauce">soy sauce</a>, salt, garlic, ginger, and <i><a href="/wiki/Gochujang" title="Gochujang">gochujang</a></i> (고추장), a hot pepper paste. Other well-known dishes are <i><a href="/wiki/Bulgogi" title="Bulgogi">Bulgogi</a></i> (불고기), grilled marinated beef, <i><a href="/wiki/Gimbap" title="Gimbap">Gimbap</a></i> (김밥), and <i><a href="/wiki/Tteokbokki" title="Tteokbokki">Tteokbokki</a></i> (떡볶이), a spicy snack consisting of rice cake seasoned with gochujang or a spicy chili paste. </p>
      <p>Soups are also a common part of a Korean meal and are served as part of the main course rather than at the beginning or the end of the meal. Soups known as <i><a href="/wiki/Guk" title="Guk">guk</a></i> (국) are often made with meats, shellfish and vegetables. Similar to guk, <i>tang</i> (탕; 湯) has less water, and is more often served in restaurants. Another type is <i><a href="/wiki/Jjigae" title="Jjigae">jjigae</a></i> (찌개), a <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stew</a> that is typically heavily seasoned with chili pepper and served boiling hot. </p>
      <p>Popular <a href="/wiki/Korean_alcoholic_beverages" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean alcoholic beverages">Korean alcoholic beverages</a> include <a href="/wiki/Soju" title="Soju">Soju</a>, <a href="/wiki/Makgeolli" title="Makgeolli">Makgeolli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bokbunja_ju" class="mw-redirect" title="Bokbunja ju">Bokbunja ju</a>. </p>
      <p>Korea is unique among East Asian countries in its use of metal <a href="/wiki/Chopstick" class="mw-redirect" title="Chopstick">chopsticks</a>. Metal chopsticks have been discovered in Goguryeo archaeological sites.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[416]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entertainment">Entertainment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Korean_Wave" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Wave">Korean Wave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_South_Korea" title="Cinema of South Korea">Cinema of South Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_drama" title="Korean drama">Korean drama</a>, and <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_(42773472410)_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_%2842773472410%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_%2842773472410%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_%2842773472410%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_%2842773472410%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_%2842773472410%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_%2842773472410%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="835" data-file-height="886"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%E2%80%98LG_Q7_BTS_%EC%97%90%EB%94%94%EC%85%98%E2%80%99_%EC%98%88%EC%95%BD_%ED%8C%90%EB%A7%A4_%EC%8B%9C%EC%9E%91_(42773472410)_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/BTS" title="BTS">BTS</a>, one of the most successful K-pop groups
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In addition to domestic consumption, South Korea has a thriving entertainment industry where various facets of South Korean entertainment, including television dramas, films, and popular music, has generated significant financial revenues for the nation's economy. The cultural phenomenon known as <i><a href="/wiki/Korean_Wave" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Wave">Hallyu</a></i> or the "Korean Wave", has swept many countries across Asia making South Korea a major soft power as an exporter of popular culture and entertainment, rivaling Western nations such as the United States and the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-Kwave_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwave-421">[417]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_%281%29.jpg/220px-20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="189" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_%281%29.jpg/330px-20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_%281%29.jpg/440px-20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="1100"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:20161119_%EB%B8%94%EB%9E%99%ED%95%91%ED%81%AC_%EB%A9%9C%EB%A1%A0%EB%AE%A4%EC%A7%81%EC%96%B4%EC%9B%8C%EB%93%9C_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The girl group <a href="/wiki/Blackpink" title="Blackpink">Blackpink</a> is the highest-charting female Korean act on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a>, peaking at number 13 with "<a href="/wiki/Ice_Cream_(Blackpink_and_Selena_Gomez_song)" title="Ice Cream (Blackpink and Selena Gomez song)">Ice Cream</a>" (2020), and on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Until the 1990s, <a href="/wiki/Trot_(music)" title="Trot (music)">trot</a> and traditional Korean <a href="/wiki/Korean_folk_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean folk music">folk based</a> ballads dominated South Korean popular music. The emergence of the South Korean pop group <a href="/wiki/Seo_Taiji_and_Boys" title="Seo Taiji and Boys">Seo Taiji and Boys</a> in 1992 marked a turning point for South Korean popular music, also known as <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a>, as the genre modernized itself from incorporating elements of popular musical genres from across the world such as <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">Western popular music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Experimental_music" title="Experimental music">experimental</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospel_music" title="Gospel music">gospel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_music_(genre)" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin music (genre)">Latin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>, <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_R%26B" title="Contemporary R&amp;B">rhythm and blues</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance" class="mw-redirect" title="Electronic dance">electronic dance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a>, <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_folk_music" title="Contemporary folk music">folk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> on top of its uniquely <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Korean_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Traditional Korean music">traditional Korean music</a> roots.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[418]</a></sup> Western-style pop, hip hop, rhythm and blues, rock, folk, electronic dance oriented acts have become dominant in the modern South Korean popular music scene, though trot is still enjoyed among older South Koreans. K-pop stars and groups are well known across Asia and have found international fame making millions of dollars in export revenue. Many K-pop acts have also been able secure a strong overseas following using online social media platforms such as the video sharing website <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a>. South Korean singer <a href="/wiki/PSY" class="mw-redirect" title="PSY">PSY</a> became an international sensation when his song "<a href="/wiki/Gangnam_Style" title="Gangnam Style">Gangnam Style</a>" topped global music charts in 2012. </p>
      <p>Since the success of the film <i><a href="/wiki/Shiri_(film)" title="Shiri (film)">Shiri</a></i> in 1999, the <a href="/wiki/Korean_film" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean film">Korean film</a> industry has begun to gain recognition internationally. Domestic film has a dominant share of the market, partly because of the existence of <a href="/wiki/Screen_quotas" title="Screen quotas">screen quotas</a> requiring cinemas to show Korean films at least 73 days a year.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[419]</a></sup> 2019's <i><a href="/wiki/Parasite_(2019_film)" title="Parasite (2019 film)">Parasite</a></i>, directed by <a href="/wiki/Bong_Joon-ho" title="Bong Joon-ho">Bong Joon Ho</a>, became the <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films_in_South_Korea" title="List of highest-grossing films in South Korea">highest-grossing film in South Korea</a> as well as the first non-English language film to win Best Picture at the United States-based <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">Academy Awards</a> <a href="/wiki/92nd_Academy_Awards" title="92nd Academy Awards">that year</a> amongst <a href="/wiki/List_of_accolades_received_by_Parasite" title="List of accolades received by Parasite">numerous other accolades</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Television_in_South_Korea" title="Television in South Korea">South Korean television shows</a> have become popular outside of Korea. South Korean television dramas, known as <a href="/wiki/Korean_drama" title="Korean drama">K-dramas</a>, have begun to find fame internationally. Many dramas tend to have a romantic focus, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Princess_Hours" title="Princess Hours">Princess Hours</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/You%27re_Beautiful_(TV_series)" title="You're Beautiful (TV series)">You're Beautiful</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Playful_Kiss" title="Playful Kiss">Playful Kiss</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/My_Name_is_Kim_Sam_Soon" class="mw-redirect" title="My Name is Kim Sam Soon">My Name is Kim Sam Soon</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Boys_Over_Flowers_(TV_series)" title="Boys Over Flowers (TV series)">Boys Over Flowers</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Winter_Sonata" title="Winter Sonata">Winter Sonata</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Autumn_in_My_Heart" title="Autumn in My Heart">Autumn in My Heart</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Full_House_(2004_TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Full House (2004 TV series)">Full House</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/City_Hunter_(TV_series)" title="City Hunter (TV series)">City Hunter</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/All_About_Eve_(South_Korean_TV_series)" title="All About Eve (South Korean TV series)">All About Eve</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Secret_Garden_(South_Korean_TV_series)" title="Secret Garden (South Korean TV series)">Secret Garden</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/I_Can_Hear_Your_Voice" title="I Can Hear Your Voice">I Can Hear Your Voice</a></i>, <i>Master's Sun</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/My_Love_from_the_Star" title="My Love from the Star">My Love from the Star</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Healer_(TV_series)" title="Healer (TV series)">Healer</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Descendants_of_the_Sun" title="Descendants of the Sun">Descendants of the Sun</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Guardian:_The_Lonely_and_Great_God" title="Guardian: The Lonely and Great God">Guardian: The Lonely and Great God</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crash_Landing_on_You" title="Crash Landing on You">Crash Landing on You</a></i>. Historical dramas have included <i>Faith</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Dae_Jang_Geum" title="Dae Jang Geum">Dae Jang Geum</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Legend_(TV_series)" title="The Legend (TV series)">The Legend</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Dong_Yi_(TV_series)" title="Dong Yi (TV series)">Dong Yi</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Moon_Embracing_the_Sun" title="Moon Embracing the Sun">Moon Embracing the Sun</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sungkyunkwan_Scandal" title="Sungkyunkwan Scandal">Sungkyunkwan Scandal</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Iljimae" title="Iljimae">Iljimae</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_(South_Korean_TV_series)" title="Kingdom (South Korean TV series)">Kingdom</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[421]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays">Holidays</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_South_Korea" title="Public holidays in South Korea">Public holidays in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Folk_dance_(South_Korea).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Folk_dance_%28South_Korea%29.jpg/220px-Folk_dance_%28South_Korea%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Folk_dance_%28South_Korea%29.jpg/330px-Folk_dance_%28South_Korea%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Folk_dance_%28South_Korea%29.jpg/440px-Folk_dance_%28South_Korea%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Folk_dance_(South_Korea).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Traditional Korean folk dance
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There are many official public holidays in South Korea. Korean New Year's Day, or "Seollal", is celebrated on the first day of the Korean lunar calendar. <a href="/wiki/March_1st_Movement" title="March 1st Movement">Korean Independence Day</a> falls on 1 March, and commemorates the 1 March Movement of 1919. Memorial Day is celebrated on 6 June, and its purpose is to honor the men and women who died in South Korea's independence movement. Constitution Day is on 17 July, and it celebrates the promulgation of <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitution of the Republic of Korea">Constitution of the Republic of Korea</a>. Liberation Day, on 15 August, celebrates Korea's liberation from the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> in 1945. Every 15th day of the 8th lunar month, Koreans celebrate the <a href="/wiki/Chuseok" title="Chuseok">Midautumn Festival</a>, in which Koreans visit their ancestral hometowns and eat a variety of traditional Korean foods. On 1 October, Armed Forces day is celebrated, honoring the military forces of South Korea. 3 October is <a href="/wiki/Gaecheonjeol" title="Gaecheonjeol">National Foundation Day</a>. Hangul Day, on 9 October commemorates the invention of <a href="/wiki/Hangul" title="Hangul">hangul</a>, the native alphabet of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean language</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_South_Korea" title="Sport in South Korea">Sport in South Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg/220px-View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg/330px-View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg/440px-View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3290" data-file-height="1854"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:View_from_COEX_Tower.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Seoul_Sports_Complex" title="Seoul Sports Complex">Seoul Sports Complex</a>, Korea's largest integrated sports center
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial art</a> <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">taekwondo</a> originated in Korea. In the 1950s and 1960s, modern rules were standardized, with taekwondo becoming an official <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic sport</a> in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[422]</a></sup> Other Korean martial arts include <a href="/wiki/Taekkyeon" title="Taekkyeon">Taekkyon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hapkido" title="Hapkido">hapkido</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tang_Soo_Do" title="Tang Soo Do">Tang Soo Do</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuk_Sool_Won" title="Kuk Sool Won">Kuk Sool Won</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kumdo" title="Kumdo">kumdo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Subak" title="Subak">subak</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">baseball</a> have traditionally been regarded as the most popular sports in Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[424]</a></sup> Recent polling indicates that a majority, 41% of South Korean sports fans continue to self-identify as football fans, with <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">baseball</a> ranked 2nd at 25% of respondents. However, the polling did not indicate the extent to which respondents follow both sports.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Korea_Republic_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Korea Republic national football team">national football team</a> became the first team in the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation" title="Asian Football Confederation">Asian Football Confederation</a> to reach the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> semi-finals in the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>, jointly hosted by South Korea and Japan. The <a href="/wiki/Korea_Republic_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Korea Republic national football team">Korea Republic national team</a> (as it is known) has qualified for every World Cup since <a href="/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1986 FIFA World Cup">Mexico 1986</a>, and has broken out of the group stage twice: first in 2002, and again in <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010</a>, when it was defeated by eventual semi-finalist <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">Uruguay</a> in the Round of 16. At the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, South Korea won the bronze medal for football. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG/220px-Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG/330px-Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG/440px-Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Busan_Sajik_Stadium_20080706.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sajik_Baseball_Stadium" class="mw-redirect" title="Sajik Baseball Stadium">Sajik Baseball Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Busan" title="Busan">Busan</a>. Baseball is one of the most popular sports in South Korea.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Baseball was first introduced to Korea in 1905 and has since become increasingly popular, with some sources claiming it has surpassed football as the most popular sport in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup> Recent years have been characterized by increasing attendance and ticket prices for professional baseball games.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[429]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[430]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Korea_Professional_Baseball" class="mw-redirect" title="Korea Professional Baseball">Korea Professional Baseball</a> league, a 10-team circuit, was established in 1982. The <a href="/wiki/South_Korea_national_baseball_team" title="South Korea national baseball team">South Korea national team</a> finished third in the <a href="/wiki/2006_World_Baseball_Classic" title="2006 World Baseball Classic">2006 World Baseball Classic</a> and second in the <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Baseball_Classic" title="2009 World Baseball Classic">2009 tournament</a>. The team's 2009 final game against Japan was widely watched in Korea, with a large screen at <a href="/wiki/Gwanghwamun" title="Gwanghwamun">Gwanghwamun</a> crossing in Seoul broadcasting the game live.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[431]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a>, South Korea won the gold medal in baseball.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[432]</a></sup> Also in 1982, at the Baseball Worldcup, Korea won the gold medal. At the <a href="/wiki/2010_Asian_Games" title="2010 Asian Games">2010 Asian Games</a>, the Korean National Baseball team won the gold medal. Several Korean players have gone on to play in <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">Basketball</a> is a popular sport in the country as well. South Korea has traditionally had one of the top basketball teams in Asia and one of the continent's strongest basketball divisions. Seoul hosted the <a href="/wiki/1967_ABC_Championship" title="1967 ABC Championship">1967</a> and <a href="/wiki/1995_ABC_Championship" title="1995 ABC Championship">1995 Asian Basketball Championship</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Korea_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Korea national basketball team">Korea national basketball team</a> has won a record number of 23 medals at the event to date.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[433]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg/220px-Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg/330px-Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg/440px-Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2860" data-file-height="2115"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Korea_Taekwondo_Hanmadang_70.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">Taekwondo</a>, a Korean martial art and Olympic sport
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>South Korea hosted the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Games" title="Asian Games">Asian Games</a> in 1986 (Seoul), 2002 (Busan), and 2014 (Incheon). It also hosted the Winter <a href="/wiki/Universiade" title="Universiade">Universiade</a> in 1997, the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Winter_Games" title="Asian Winter Games">Asian Winter Games</a> in 1999, and the Summer Universiade in 2003 and 2015. In 1988, South Korea hosted the <a href="/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics" title="1988 Summer Olympics">Summer Olympics in Seoul</a>, coming fourth with 12 gold medals, 10 silver medals, and 11 bronze medals. South Korea regularly performs well in <a href="/wiki/Archery" title="Archery">archery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shooting" title="Shooting">shooting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating" title="Short track speed skating">short track speed skating</a>, <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">handball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">field hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">freestyle wrestling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_wrestling" title="Greco-Roman wrestling">Greco-Roman wrestling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">baseball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">judo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">taekwondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Speed_skating" title="Speed skating">speed skating</a>, <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">figure skating</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifting</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Olympic_Museum" title="Seoul Olympic Museum">Seoul Olympic Museum</a> is dedicated to the 1988 Summer Olympics. On 6 July 2011, <a href="/wiki/Pyeongchang_County" title="Pyeongchang County">Pyeongchang</a> was chosen by the <a href="/wiki/IOC" class="mw-redirect" title="IOC">IOC</a> to host the <a href="/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics" title="2018 Winter Olympics">2018 Winter Olympics</a>. </p>
      <p>South Korea has won more medals in the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Winter Olympics">Winter Olympics</a> than any other Asian country, with a total of 45 (23 gold, 14 silver, and 8 bronze). At the <a href="/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics" title="2010 Winter Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a>, South Korea ranked fifth in the overall medal rankings. South Korea is especially strong in <a href="/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating" title="Short track speed skating">short track speed skating</a>. <a href="/wiki/Speed_skating" title="Speed skating">Speed skating</a> and <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">figure skating</a> are also popular, and <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> is an emerging sport, with <a href="/wiki/Anyang_Halla" title="Anyang Halla">Anyang Halla</a> winning their first ever <a href="/wiki/Asia_League_Ice_Hockey" title="Asia League Ice Hockey">Asia League Ice Hockey</a> title in March 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[434]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Seoul hosted a professional <a href="/wiki/Triathlon" title="Triathlon">triathlon</a> race, which is part of the <a href="/wiki/International_Triathlon_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="International Triathlon Union">International Triathlon Union</a> (ITU) World Championship Series in May 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[435]</a></sup> In 2011, the South Korean city of Daegu hosted the <a href="/wiki/2011_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2011 World Championships in Athletics">2011 IAAF World Championships in Athletics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[436]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In October 2010, South Korea hosted its first <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> race at the <a href="/wiki/Korea_International_Circuit" title="Korea International Circuit">Korea International Circuit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Yeongam" class="mw-redirect" title="Yeongam">Yeongam</a>, about 400 kilometres (250&nbsp;mi) south of Seoul.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[437]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Korean_Grand_Prix" title="Korean Grand Prix">Korean Grand Prix</a> was held from 2010 to 2013, but was not placed on the <a href="/wiki/2014_Formula_One_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Formula One season">2014 F1 calendar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[438]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Domestic <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a> events are also followed by South Koreans and <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Race_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Seoul Race Park">Seoul Race Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Gwacheon" title="Gwacheon">Gwacheon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gyeonggi-do" class="mw-redirect" title="Gyeonggi-do">Gyeonggi-do</a> is located closest to Seoul out of the country's three tracks.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[439]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Competitive <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">video gaming</a>, also called <a href="/wiki/Esports" title="Esports">Esports</a> (sometimes written e-Sports), has become more popular in South Korea in recent years, particularly among young people.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[440]</a></sup> The two most popular games are <a href="/wiki/League_of_Legends" title="League of Legends">League of Legends</a> and <a href="/wiki/StarCraft" title="StarCraft">StarCraft</a>. The gaming scene of South Korea is managed by the <a href="/wiki/Korean_e-Sports_Association" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean e-Sports Association">Korean e-Sports Association</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">No official data regarding ethnicity is collected by the South Korean government. At the end of 2015, approximately 4% of the population are foreigners.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Christian-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Christian_5-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">19.7% are <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestant</a>, 7.9% are <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_South_Korea" title="Catholic Church in South Korea">Catholic</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>: <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD" class="extiw" title="wikt:한국">한국</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%9F%93%E5%9C%8B" class="extiw" title="wikt:韓國">韓國</a>, <a href="/wiki/Revised_Romanization_of_Korean" title="Revised Romanization of Korean">RR</a>: <i>Hanguk</i>; literally <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EB%82%A8%ED%95%9C" class="extiw" title="wikt:남한">남한</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8D%97%E9%9F%93" class="extiw" title="wikt:南韓">南韓</a>, <a href="/wiki/Revised_Romanization_of_Korean" title="Revised Romanization of Korean">RR</a>: <i>Namhan</i>, or <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EB%82%A8%EC%A1%B0%EC%84%A0" class="extiw" title="wikt:남조선">남조선</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8D%97%E6%9C%9D%E9%AE%AE" class="extiw" title="wikt:南朝鮮">南朝鮮</a>, <a href="/wiki/McCune%E2%80%93Reischauer" title="McCune–Reischauer">MR</a>: <i>Namchosŏn</i> in North Korean usage</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Korean: <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD" class="extiw" title="wikt:대한민국">대한민국</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%A7%E9%9F%93%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B" class="extiw" title="wikt:大韓民國">大韓民國</a>, <a href="/wiki/Revised_Romanization_of_Korean" title="Revised Romanization of Korean">RR</a>: <i>Daehan Minguk</i></span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

         <li id="cite_note-Kim-Shon-Chosunilbo2016-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kim-Shon-Chosunilbo2016_6-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKimShon2016" class="citation news cs1">Kim, Han-soo; Shon, Jin-seok (20 December 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2016/12/20/2016122000155.html"><bdi lang="ko">신자 수, 개신교 1위… "종교 없다" 56%</bdi></a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Chosun_Ilbo" class="mw-redirect" title="Chosun Ilbo">Chosun Ilbo</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREF이기환2017" class="citation web cs1">이기환 (30 August 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201708300913001&amp;code=960100&amp;www"><bdi lang="ko">[이기환의 흔적의 역사]국호논쟁의 전말…대한민국이냐 고려공화국이냐</bdi></a>. <bdi lang="ko">경향신문</bdi> (in Korean). The Kyunghyang Shinmun<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 July</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%5B%EC%9D%B4%EA%B8%B0%ED%99%98%EC%9D%98+%ED%9D%94%EC%A0%81%EC%9D%98+%EC%97%AD%EC%82%AC%5D%EA%B5%AD%ED%98%B8%EB%85%BC%EC%9F%81%EC%9D%98+%EC%A0%84%EB%A7%90%E2%80%A6%EB%8C%80%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B4%EB%83%90+%EA%B3%A0%EB%A0%A4%EA%B3%B5%ED%99%94%EA%B5%AD%EC%9D%B4%EB%83%90&amp;rft.pub=The+Kyunghyang+Shinmun&amp;rft.date=2017-08-30&amp;rft.au=%EC%9D%B4%EA%B8%B0%ED%99%98&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.khan.co.kr%2Fkh_news%2Fkhan_art_view.html%3Fartid%3D201708300913001%26code%3D960100%26www&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREF이덕일" class="citation web cs1">이덕일. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2008/08/14/2008081401512.html"><bdi lang="ko">[이덕일 사랑] 대~한민국</bdi></a>. <bdi lang="ko">조선닷컴</bdi> (in Korean). Chosun Ilbo<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 July</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%5B%EC%9D%B4%EB%8D%95%EC%9D%BC+%EC%82%AC%EB%9E%91%5D+%EB%8C%80~%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD&amp;rft.pub=Chosun+Ilbo&amp;rft.au=%EC%9D%B4%EB%8D%95%EC%9D%BC&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.chosun.com%2Fsite%2Fdata%2Fhtml_dir%2F2008%2F08%2F14%2F2008081401512.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-unloved-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-unloved_41-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-unloved_41-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMyers2016" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">Myers, Brian Reynolds</a> (28 December 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sthelepress.com/index.php/2016/12/28/still-the-unloved-republic/">"Still the Unloved Republic"</a>. <i>Sthele Press</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 June</span> 2019</span>. <q><i>Taehan minguk</i>. In English it is translated as Republic of Korea or South Korea, names which to us foreigners denote the state as a political entity distinct from its northern neighbor. To most people here, however, <i>Taehan minguk</i> conveys that sense only when used in contrastive proximity with the word <i>Pukhan</i> (North Korea). Ask South Koreans when the <i>Taehan minguk</i> was established; more will answer '5000 years ago' than 'in 1948,' because to them it is simply the full name for <i>Hanguk</i>, Korea, the homeland. That’s all it meant to most people who shouted those four syllables so proudly during the World Cup in 2002.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Sthele+Press&amp;rft.atitle=Still+the+Unloved+Republic&amp;rft.date=2016-12-28&amp;rft.aulast=Myers&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian+Reynolds&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsthelepress.com%2Findex.php%2F2016%2F12%2F28%2Fstill-the-unloved-republic%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-thefreelibrary.com-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-thefreelibrary.com_42-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMyers2018" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">Myers, Brian Reynolds</a> (20 May 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20180520092751/https://www.thefreelibrary.com/North+Korea's+state-loyalty+advantage.-a0274114570">"North Korea's state-loyalty advantage"</a>. <i>Free Online Library</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.thefreelibrary.com/North+Korea's+state-loyalty+advantage.-a0274114570">the original</a> on 20 May 2018.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Free+Online+Library&amp;rft.atitle=North+Korea%27s+state-loyalty+advantage.&amp;rft.date=2018-05-20&amp;rft.aulast=Myers&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian+Reynolds&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thefreelibrary.com%2FNorth%2BKorea%27s%2Bstate-loyalty%2Badvantage.-a0274114570&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-print_a-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-print_a_43-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-print_a_43-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100128065300/http://www.asianinfo.org/asianinfo/korea/history.htm">"Korea's History"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-DangunGija-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-DangunGija_51-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-DangunGija_51-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">* 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSeth2010" class="citation book cs1">Seth, Michael J. (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WJtMGXyGlUEC&amp;pg=PA443"><i>A History of Korea: From Antiquity to the Present</i></a>. Rowman &amp; Littlefield Publishers. p.&nbsp;443. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7425-6717-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7425-6717-7"><bdi>978-0-7425-6717-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Korea%3A+From+Antiquity+to+the+Present&amp;rft.pages=443&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+%26+Littlefield+Publishers&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7425-6717-7&amp;rft.aulast=Seth&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWJtMGXyGlUEC%26pg%3DPA443&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span> 
           <dl>
            <dd>
             "An extreme manifestation of nationalism and the family cult was the revival of interest in Tangun, the mythical founder of the first Korean state... Most textbooks and professional historians, however, treat him as a myth."
            </dd>
           </dl> 
           <ul>
            <li>
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFStark2008" class="citation book cs1">Stark, Miriam T. (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=z4_bT2SJ-HUC&amp;pg=PA49"><i>Archaeology of Asia</i></a>. John Wiley &amp; Sons. p.&nbsp;49. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4051-5303-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4051-5303-4"><bdi>978-1-4051-5303-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Archaeology+of+Asia&amp;rft.pages=49&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4051-5303-4&amp;rft.aulast=Stark&amp;rft.aufirst=Miriam+T.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dz4_bT2SJ-HUC%26pg%3DPA49&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></li>
           </ul> 
           <dl>
            <dd>
             "Although Kija may have truly existed as a historical figure, Tangun is more problematical."
            </dd>
           </dl>

            <li>
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSchmid2013" class="citation book cs1">Schmid, Andre (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lVgaAwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA269"><i>Korea Between Empires</i></a>.
